choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria engulfed by macrophages
﻿﻿﻿Neutrophil engulfed bacteria
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria arranged in clusters

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

 

The microscopic finding described is consistent with "clue cells," which are a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis (BV). Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that are covered with a stippled appearance due to bacteria adhering to their surface. This attachment creates a poorly defined border on the cell. Clue cells are significant in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis because they are a reliable indicator of this condition. For a diagnosis of BV, at least 20 percent of epithelial cells in a wet mount preparation should appear as clue cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacteria engulfed by macrophages: This finding is more indicative of an inflammatory response and is not characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. It is more commonly associated with other types of infections or inflammatory conditions.

 

Option C. Neutrophil engulfed bacteria: This description is associated with acute bacterial infections or inflammation but not with bacterial vaginosis, where clue cells are the key finding.

 

Option D. Bacteria arranged in clusters: While bacteria may be present in clusters in some infections, this description does not specifically identify the clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells, which are epithelial cells with bacteria attached on their surface, are the most reliable microscopic indicator of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: The gold standard investigation for diagnosing endometriosis is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopy

 

Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard investigation for diagnosing endometriosis. This minimally invasive surgical procedure allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs, enabling the identification of endometriotic lesions.

 

During laparoscopy, biopsies can be taken from suspected areas, which are then examined histologically to confirm the presence of endometriosis.

 

While other imaging techniques, such as transvaginal ultrasound or MRI, can suggest the presence of endometriosis, particularly in the case of endometriotic cysts (also known as chocolate cysts), they may miss smaller or less obvious lesions. Laparoscopy, therefore, provides a definitive diagnosis by allowing direct inspection and biopsy of the lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: This imaging technique is useful as an initial investigation, especially for detecting endometriotic ovarian cysts, but it is not as comprehensive as laparoscopy for diagnosing all forms of endometriosis.

 

Option B. MRI: MRI can provide detailed images and is useful in some cases, particularly for deep infiltrating endometriosis, but it is not as definitive as laparoscopy.

 

Option C. CT scan: CT scans are not typically used for diagnosing endometriosis due to their lower sensitivity for detecting endometriotic lesions compared to laparoscopy and other imaging modalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopy is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing endometriosis because it allows direct visualization and biopsy of endometriotic lesions, providing a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A G2 with a previous LSCS underwent cesarean delivery. During surgery, there was excessive bleeding, and a hysterectomy had to be done. The image of the uterus is shown. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Placenta accrete syndrome


Placenta accrete syndrome (PAS) includes conditions where the placenta abnormally attaches to the uterus, such as placenta accreta, increta, and percreta. In this case, the image and description of the uterus with the placenta still attached indicate PAS. The typical presentation involves severe intraoperative bleeding because the placenta does not detach easily from the uterine wall, necessitating an obstetric hysterectomy to control the hemorrhage. This condition is common in patients with a history of cesarean sections (LSCS) due to scarring in the uterine wall, making placental attachment more likely. Diagnosing PAS antenatally can alter management strategies, such as planning an elective upper segment cesarean section between 34-37 weeks and avoiding the lower uterine segment to minimize bleeding and complications. After delivering the baby, the placenta should be left in situ, followed by an immediate obstetric hysterectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta covers the cervix, leading to painless bleeding during pregnancy but not typically associated with an adherent placenta that requires hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves premature placental detachment from the uterine wall, leading to painful bleeding. However, it does not involve a placenta that remains attached and does not generally necessitate a hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: Uterine rupture involves a tear in the uterine wall, often resulting from previous uterine surgeries. It presents with acute pain and significant bleeding, but the description and image do not match the typical findings of PAS.

 

Educational Objective:


Placenta accrete syndrome involves abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall, often leading to severe bleeding during delivery and requiring obstetric hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient was found to have uterus didelphys. Which of the following is not likely to be a complication of this uterine anomaly? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis: Endometriosis can occur in patients with uterus didelphys, particularly in the rare variant known as OHVIRA syndrome (Obstructed Hemi Vagina with Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis), where menstrual blood can become trapped, leading to retrograde menstruation and endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abortion: Spontaneous abortion is a potential complication associated with uterus didelphys due to the structural anomaly affecting the uterine environment.

 

Option C. Preterm labor: Preterm labor is a recognized complication in patients with uterus didelphys. The abnormal structure of the uterus can lead to difficulties in carrying the pregnancy to full term.

 

Option D. Transverse lie: Among the given options, transverse lie is not a likely complication of uterus didelphys. A transverse lie is more commonly associated with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus, rather than uterus didelphys. Uterus didelphys usually has a better reproductive outcome compared to other uterine anomalies, though it still presents with certain risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterus didelphys is associated with complications such as spontaneous abortion, preterm labor, and endometriosis, but it is less likely to cause a transverse lie, which is more common in arcuate or sub-septate uteri.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7231278/

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leaves of broad ligament

 

Explanation:

 

Leaves of broad ligament:

 

  • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men.
  • In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy.
  • As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include:
    • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni: Located lateral to the fallopian tube.
    • Koblet’s tubules: Found in the outer part of the broad ligament.
    • Epoophoron: Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube.
    • Para-oophoron: Situated between the ovary and the uterus.
    • Gartner’s duct: Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pouch of Douglas: This is the rectouterine pouch, a space between the uterus and the rectum, and is not associated with remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Option C. Uterovesical pouch: This is the space between the uterus and the bladder and does not contain Wolffian duct remnants.

 

Option D. Iliac fossa: This is an anatomical region of the pelvis, and it is not related to the remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The remnants of the Wolffian ducts in females are found in the leaves of the broad ligament and the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? 

 

  1. Headache
  2. Blurred vision
  3. Persistent pedal edema
  4. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Imminent eclampsia is indicated by the presence of severe symptoms in a patient with preeclampsia. The following symptoms are particularly concerning and suggest the risk of progression to eclampsia:

 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Epigastric pain
  • Vomiting (though not listed in the options)

 

Key Points:

 

1. Headache: Severe, persistent headache is a sign of central nervous system involvement.

 

2. Blurred vision: Visual disturbances such as blurred vision or seeing spots are due to cerebral or retinal vasospasm.

 

4. Epigastric pain: Pain in the epigastric or right upper quadrant can indicate hepatic involvement, such as stretching of the Glisson capsule due to liver swelling.

 

Other symptoms not specifically listed:

 

  • Vomiting: This can also be a sign of worsening preeclampsia.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Persistent pedal edema : While edema can be present in preeclampsia, it is not a specific indicator of imminent eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with preeclampsia, the presence of headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain indicates imminent eclampsia and necessitates immediate intervention with prophylactic magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) and planning for delivery to prevent the onset of seizures.

 

Ref: Williams text book of obstetrics 26th edition Pg 1840, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics pg 261,262

choices.text: Contraction stress test

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of fetal biophysical profile? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Contraction stress test

 

The fetal biophysical profile (BPP) is a comprehensive assessment used to evaluate fetal well-being, and it includes five components:

 

  1. NST (Non-Stress Test): Evaluates fetal heart rate reactivity.
  2. Amniotic Fluid Volume (AFV): Assessed through ultrasound to check the amount of amniotic fluid.
  3. Fetal Movement: Observes fetal movements through ultrasound.
  4. Fetal Tone: Evaluates the presence of fetal muscle tone and limb movements.
  5. Fetal Breathing: Assesses the presence and duration of fetal breathing movements.

 

The Contraction Stress Test (CST) is not part of the BPP. Instead, it is a separate test used to assess the fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions, helping to evaluate how well the fetus handles the stress of contractions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal movement: This is a component of the BPP, assessing the number of fetal movements.

 

Option B. Fetal breathing: This is a component of the BPP, evaluating the presence of fetal breathing movements.

 

Option C. NST: The Non-Stress Test is a key component of the BPP, measuring fetal heart rate reactivity to movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Contraction Stress Test is not a component of the fetal biophysical profile.

 

Ref: Page no 122, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in a patient with atonic PPH with a history of hypertension? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergotamine

 

Ergotamine (or methylergometrine) is an ergot alkaloid that is commonly used as a uterotonic agent to manage postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) by promoting uterine contractions. However, it has potent vasoconstrictive properties, which significantly increase vascular resistance and blood pressure.

 

In patients with a history of hypertension, the use of ergotamine is contraindicated because its vasoconstrictive effect can lead to a dangerous rise in blood pressure. This increase in afterload can put additional strain on the heart and may precipitate hypertensive crises or other cardiovascular complications. Therefore, ergotamine is avoided in hypertensive patients, particularly in those with chronic hypertension or other cardiovascular diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue that is also used to manage postpartum hemorrhage. It induces uterine contractions but does not have significant vasoconstrictive effects. Therefore, it is not contraindicated in patients with hypertension.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is another uterotonic agent that works by stimulating uterine contractions. While it can cause mild vasodilation, it does not have the strong vasoconstrictive properties of ergotamine and is generally safe to use in hypertensive patients.

 

Option D. PGF2 alpha: Certain prostaglandins can increase blood pressure and should be used with caution, but they are not as strongly contraindicated as ergotamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotamine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects, which can significantly increase blood pressure and cause cardiovascular complications. This drug should be avoided in hypertensive patients, especially when managing postpartum hemorrhage.

choices.text: Dark ground microscopy

questions.text: A pregnant female visited the obstetrics and gynecology outpatient department (OBG OPD) for her regular prenatal examination. Her past pregnancy involved a stillbirth at 28 weeks. She has a history of engaging in sexual relations with multiple partners and recalls a painless sore on her vulva before her previous pregnancy. What initial investigative step should be taken for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VDRL

 

The given scenario with a pregnant female has a history of stillbirth and painless genital ulcer is suggestive of Syphilis. So, Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) will be the first investigation to be done.

 

SYPHILIS IN PREGNANCY

 

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum
  • Primary Syphilis – Characterized by painless, nontender, single papule over the genitalia, that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, and is called a hard chancre.
  • Kassowitz Law – gradually improving fetal outcomes in congenital syphilis
  • Screening test – VDRL (done for all antenatal patients; May be false positive)
  • USG: FGR, hepatomegaly, fetal anemia, hydrops, placentomegaly
  • Treatment – Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million U

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HIV ELISA: HIV ELISA is done routinely for screening antenatal patients.

 

Option C. Dark ground microscopy: Dark ground microscopy is done when an active ulcer is present.

 

Option D. Culture: Treponema pallidum can’t be cultured. It is not the preferred method to diagnose or screen syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pregnant woman with a history of stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, the initial investigation should be the VDRL test to screen for syphilis, as syphilis can significantly impact pregnancy outcomes and requires prompt treatment.

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period
Beta HCG estimation
Serum FSH and LH

questions.text: A patient has been on MALA-N for 6 months. She is compliant, but she complained of missed periods. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta HCG estimation

 

MALA-N is a combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP). Despite high compliance, all contraceptive methods have a failure rate. The first consideration for a missed period in a woman of reproductive age is pregnancy. Therefore, the next step is to estimate beta HCG levels to rule out pregnancy.

 

  • Beta HCG Estimation: This is essential to confirm or rule out pregnancy. Serum beta HCG can detect pregnancy as early as five days before the first missed period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: This is not the initial step. It is more appropriate once pregnancy is confirmed or other issues are suspected.

 

Option B. Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period: While some irregularity can occur with OCPs, pregnancy must be ruled out first.

 

Option D. Serum FSH and LH: These tests are used to evaluate ovarian function but are not appropriate for initial evaluation of a missed period in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a woman on combined oral contraceptive pills presents with a missed period, the first step is to rule out pregnancy by estimating beta HCG levels.

 

Ref: Page no 622, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented in OBG emergency with 38 weeks of amenorrhea. She is in first stage of labour and on examination, cervical dilatation is 6 cm. According to you, what will be a satisfactory dilatation rate? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1.2 cm/hr

 

Explanation:

 

In a nullipara, 1.2 cm/hr is the best dilatation rate among given options.

 

First stage of labour has 2 phases:

 

 

  • Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a primi is 1 cm/h
  • Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a multi is 1.5 cm/h

 

 

The WHO Labour Care guide (2021) differs from the earlier partograph in the following ways:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a primi is 1 cm/h

 

Ref: WHO labour care guide Users Manual 2021

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

 

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

 

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

 

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

 

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.

 

A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.

 

Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: Choose the best option to define a post-term neonate: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Born after 42 weeks of gestation

 

Post-term neonates are those who are born after 42 weeks / 294 days of gestation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Based on the above table

 

Option A. Born after 37 weeks of gestation:  early term (37 to 38 6/7  )

 

Option B. Born after 40 weeks of gestation: Late term between 41 to 41 6/7 and  Full term: between 39 to 40 6/7  and

 

Option D. Born between 37 – 40 weeks of gestation: Term pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-term neonates are those who are born after 42 weeks / 294 days of gestation.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, chapter on preterm labor

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start LMWH.
Stop warfarin and start heparin.
Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy 4mg/ day. What is the appropriate next step in management. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH.

 

Explanation:

 

Stop warfarin and start LMWH: Warfarin is teratogenic and has a significant risk of causing warfarin embryopathy, particularly in doses greater than 5mg per day. In pregnancy, it is recommended to change warfarin to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) in the first trimester, especially if the warfarin dose exceeds 5 mg/day. After 13 weeks, it can be switched back to warfarin until delivery. Near delivery, warfarin should again be replaced by LMWH or UFH to manage the risk of bleeding complications during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop warfarin and start heparin: This option is partially correct as it aligns with the practice of switching from warfarin to a safer anticoagulant near delivery. However, the preferred anticoagulant in this situation is LMWH due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and ease of administration.

 

Option C. Continue warfarin: This is incorrect because continuing warfarin at 36 weeks of gestation poses significant risks of fetal hemorrhage and warfarin embryopathy. It is essential to switch to a safer anticoagulant like LMWH or UFH close to delivery.

 

Option D. Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin: While this option includes stopping warfarin and starting LMWH, which is correct, the addition of aspirin is only indicated in women who are at a very high risk of thrombosis. The general recommendation does not include aspirin unless there is a specific high-risk indication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin should be replaced by low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) near delivery to manage the risks associated with its teratogenic effects and potential complications during delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 2404, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) updated its guidelines in 2016, recommending a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality. This guideline is structured to ensure comprehensive monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy:

 

  1. 1st Trimester:
    • Contact 1: up to 12 weeks
  2. 2nd Trimester:
    • Contact 2: at 20 weeks
    • Contact 3: at 26 weeks
  3. 3rd Trimester:
    • Contact 4: at 30 weeks
    • Contact 5: at 34 weeks
    • Contact 6: at 36 weeks
    • Contact 7: at 38 weeks
    • Contact 8: at 40 weeks

 

These visits are designed to monitor the health of the mother and fetus, provide timely interventions, and offer essential health education.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality.

 

Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).

choices.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume
Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile (BPP) except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

 

Explanation:

 

  • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia.
  • BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.
  • The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score
    • NST
    • Amniotic Fluid Volume
    • Fetal movement
    • Fetal Tone
    • Fetal Breathing

   

 

  • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia
  • Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score
  • A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH.
  • An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.
  • Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH
  • The Modified BPP has 2 components
    • NST
    • AFI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume: This statement is true. The BPP includes assessments of fetal breathing, movements, tone, and the Amniotic fluid volume as part of its evaluation.

 

Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH: This statement is true. The BPP score helps predict fetal outcome and provides an indication of fetal pH, reflecting the level of fetal distress.

 

Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia: This statement is true. A BPP score of less than 4 correlates with a fetal pH <7.2, and a score of 0 is almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) provides a consistent prediction of fetal pH and outcome, with a lower score correlating with increased risk of fetal acidemia.

 

Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

choices.text: Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes
Clear colorless to pale yellow

questions.text: Which of the following are the features of the color of normal amniotic fluid during? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clear colorless to pale yellow

 

Explanation:

 

The color of normal amniotic fluid varies during pregnancy and can indicate different conditions:

 

  • In early pregnancy: The amniotic fluid is colorless.
  • Near term: It becomes straw-colored.
  • Deep yellow/golden color: This can indicate fetal anemia.
  • Green (meconium-stained): Indicates fetal distress or post-maturity.
  • Red: Suggests abruption.
  • Dark colored/tobacco-like: Indicates fetal demise.

 

Normal amniotic fluid should be clear, colorless, or pale yellow, especially in the earlier stages of pregnancy and near term when the fluid changes to a straw color.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes: This description is not characteristic of normal amniotic fluid. Such a color can indicate the presence of infection or contamination.

 

Option B. Amber colored: Amber-colored amniotic fluid is not a normal finding and may indicate complications such as the presence of blood or other abnormalities.

 

Option D. Golden color: Golden-colored amniotic fluid typically indicates fetal anemia, which is a pathological condition and not a feature of normal amniotic fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal amniotic fluid is clear, colorless to pale yellow, changing to straw-colored near term.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 43, William’s text book of obstetrics 24th edition pg 298

choices.text: Placenta membranacea
Placenta succenturiata
Circumvallate placenta

questions.text: A pregnant woman delivered a baby with the normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half an hour she started bleeding per vaginal. On examination, she was hypotensive, and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. Ultrasound showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta succenturiate

 

  • It is mentioned here that the placenta expelled looked normal and intact
  • In such a case, if there is a retained component, it could be a succenturiate lobe
  • Placenta succenturiata refers to a placenta with an additional lobe/lobes of placental tissue located a few centimeters away.
  • The ancillary lobes can be associated with complications such as placenta previa, vasa previa, postpartum hemorrhage or infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta membranacea:

 

  • Placenta membranacea is a rare placental disorder characterized by the presence of fetal membranes (complete or partially) covered by chorionic villi.
  • Associated with painless vaginal bleeding in the second and third trimester
  • This condition can be associated with other placental abnormalities, such as placenta previa or accreta.
  • Perinatal outcome may include stillbirth, preterm delivery, or neonatal death.

 

 

Option C. Circummarginate placenta:

 

  • Uncommon variation in placental morphology in which a thin fibrous ring is present at the margin of the chorionic plate where the fetal vessels appear to terminate.
  • The placenta is unduly large and thin. The placenta not only develops from the chorion frondosum but also from the chorion laeve so that the whole of the ovum is practically covered by the placenta
  • Associated with Abortion, Hydrorrhea gravidarum (excessive watery vaginal discharge), Antepartum hemorrhage, Growth retardation of the baby, Preterm delivery and Retained placenta or membranes.

 

 

Option D. Circumvallate placenta:

 

  • The fetal surface is divided into a central depressed zone surrounded by a thickened white ring which is usually complete.
  • The ring is situated at varying distances from the margin of the placenta. The ring is composed of a double fold of amnion and chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between
  • Vessels radiate from the cord insertion as far as the ring and then disappear from view
  • The peripheral zone outside the ring is thicker and the edge is elevated and rounded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta succenturiata is characterized by an additional lobe of placental tissue separate from the main placenta, which can be retained postpartum, leading to hemorrhage and requiring careful monitoring and management.

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis from the given clinical image?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterocervical prolapse

 

The clinical image shows a case of uterocervical prolapse. This condition is common in elderly women due to weak pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism, leading to a downward displacement of the uterus and cervix into the vaginal canal.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Uterocervical Prolapse: The uterus and cervix descend into the vaginal canal, often visualized clearly as in the image provided.
  • Differential Diagnoses:
    • Cervical carcinoma: Typically presents with a growth or ulceration on the cervix, which is not seen in this image.
    • Uterine inversion: Characterized by the uterus turning inside out, where the cervical rim would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion.
    • Fibroid polyp: Would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up in its anatomical position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: The image does not show any growth or ulceration, which are typical features of cervical carcinoma.

 

Option B. Uterine inversion: In uterine inversion, the cervix would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. Fibroid polyp: A fibroid polyp would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical image showing clear visualization of the cervix along with the prolapsed uterus indicates uterocervical prolapse, a condition often seen in elderly women due to weakened pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg548, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 224

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Episiotomy scissors

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument given in the picture is an episiotomy scissors.
  • The angulation in the scissor is to prevent extension of pelvic tear into the anal margins and obstetric anal sphincter injuries / complete perineal tear.
  • An episiotomy is NOT given routinely.
  • It’s use is restricted and is given in situations like.
    • Macrosomia
    • After coming head of breech
    • Instrumental delivery
    • Shoulder dystocia

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Curved artery: It has serrated tips and ratchet lock . It is used to clamp blood vessels, hold peritoneal edges, tissue dissection

 

 

Option C. Curved mayo scissors: These are used to cut tissue such as the uterus, rectus sheath etc.

 

 

Option D. Mosquito forceps: It is a small artery forceps used to catch small bleeders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed with an angulated blade to prevent the extension of pelvic tears into the anal margins, thereby reducing the risk of obstetric anal sphincter injuries and complete perineal tears during childbirth.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 755

questions.text: The 1st sign to be seen in Mg toxicity in a patient receiving MgSO4 for eclampsia is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes)

 

The correct answer is Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes). When administering magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for eclampsia, it is crucial to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity. The first clinical sign indicating toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes.

 

Detailed Explanation:

 

  • Magnesium Sulfate in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is used to prevent seizures in patients with eclampsia. While effective, it has a narrow therapeutic range, making monitoring for toxicity essential.
  • Monitoring Signs:
    • Loss of DTRs: This is the earliest sign of magnesium toxicity. Clinicians regularly check for the presence of deep tendon reflexes to ensure they are intact.
    • Respiratory Depression: Following the loss of DTRs, respiratory depression can occur if magnesium levels continue to rise.
    • Cardiac Arrest: In severe cases, unchecked magnesium toxicity can lead to cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac arrhythmias: While significant, this is a later sign of magnesium toxicity and typically occurs after respiratory depression.

 

Option B. Hypotonia: This can be a symptom of magnesium toxicity but is not the first sign observed.

 

Option D. Respiratory depression: This follows the loss of deep tendon reflexes and is a critical sign of advancing magnesium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs) is the first clinical sign of magnesium toxicity in patients receiving MgSO4 for eclampsia. Continuous monitoring of DTRs is crucial to detect early toxicity and prevent severe complications.

choices.text: Both (a) and (b)

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Third trimester

 

Explanation:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a life-threatening medical disorder that primarily affects the liver during pregnancy. It most commonly manifests in the late second and third trimesters. AFLP is characterized by the accumulation of microvesicular fat within hepatocytes, leading to liver dysfunction. The diagnosis of AFLP is made using the Swansea criteria, which require six or more of the following clinical features for diagnosis:

 

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia, polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • Coagulopathy (raised PT, aPTT)
  • Increased bilirubin
  • Increased uric acid levels
  • Increased creatinine
  • Leukocytosis
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised serum ammonia levels
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • Microvascular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Risk Factors:

 

  • Maternal obesity
  • Male fetus
  • Primigravida
  • Multiple pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First trimester: AFLP is very rare in the first trimester, as it typically manifests later in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Second trimester: While AFLP can begin in the late second trimester, it is more commonly seen in the third trimester.

 

Option D. Both (a) and (b): AFLP does not commonly manifest in the first trimester and is primarily a condition of the late second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy most commonly manifests in the third trimester and is diagnosed using the Swansea criteria, requiring six or more specific clinical features.

 

Ref: Page no 2684, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: All of the following coagulation factors increase in pregnancy except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XI

 

Pregnancy induces a hypercoagulable state to prepare the body for the increased risk of bleeding during delivery. This state is characterized by an increase in several coagulation factors, which enhances clot formation.

 

  • Factor II (Prothrombin): Increases during pregnancy. This contributes to a higher risk of clotting.
  • Factor VII: Increases during pregnancy, aiding in the clotting process.
  • Factor VIII: Also increases during pregnancy, enhancing clotting factors and overall coagulation.
  • Factor XI: Does not increase during pregnancy. In fact, Factor XI levels are slightly decreased in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor II: Factor II increases during pregnancy, contributing to the hypercoagulable state.

 

Option B. Factor VII: Factor VII levels increase during pregnancy, supporting the increased coagulation needed.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Factor VIII increases during pregnancy, which is consistent with the overall increase in clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XI is the coagulation factor that does not increase during pregnancy and may actually decrease slightly.

 

Ref: Page no 508, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: The following groups of people must be screened for Ca cervix: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 25 to 65-year-old females

 

Explanation:

 

According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the American Cancer Society (ACS) guidelines (2020), cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years. The guidelines specify the following:

 

ACOG/ACS Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 25.
  • Ages 25 to 65:
    • HPV testing every 5 years (preferred).
    • HPV/Pap co-testing every 5 years (acceptable).
    • Pap test alone every 3 years (acceptable).
  • Age >65: No testing required if a series of previous tests were normal.

 

WHO Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 30.
  • Primary mode of screening: HPV testing.
  • Frequency: Every 5 to 10 years.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. More than 65 years old: Screening is generally not required for women over 65 if they have had a series of normal screening results.

 

Option B. Less than 25 years old: Screening is not recommended for women under 25 according to ACOG/ACS guidelines.

 

Option D. Teenagers: Screening is not recommended for teenagers as cervical cancer is extremely rare in this age group and the benefits of screening do not outweigh the potential harms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years, with various acceptable methods and intervals as specified by the ACOG and ACS guidelines.

 

Ref: ACOG guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, WHO guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 634, 635.

questions.text: During management of a labor in case of shoulder dystocia, a maneuver was done as shown below. This maneuver is known as? (FMGE jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cleidotomy

 

Explanation:

 

Cleidotomy is intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal.

 

The table below enlists the manoeuvres used in the management of shoulder dystocia including the options A B C D

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cleidotomy is an intentional fetal clavicular fracture performed to reduce the shoulder girdle diameter in cases of shoulder dystocia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition Page 469-470

questions.text:
Which of the following symptoms are seen in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Infertility
  2. Dysmenorrhea
  3. Vaginal discharge
  4. Vaginal bleeding
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows outside the uterus. This condition is associated with specific symptoms:

 

1. Infertility: Women with endometriosis often experience difficulty conceiving. The presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus can interfere with the reproductive organs, leading to infertility.

 

2. Dysmenorrhea: Painful menstruation is a hallmark of endometriosis. This condition can cause severe menstrual cramps due to the endometrial tissue responding to hormonal changes as it would in a normal menstrual cycle.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 3, 4: Vaginal discharge and vaginal bleeding are not characteristic symptoms of endometriosis. Vaginal discharge may be seen in various other conditions but is not specific to endometriosis. Similarly, while endometriosis can cause abnormal bleeding, it typically presents with pain rather than increased vaginal bleeding.

 

Option B. 2, 3: While dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) is a symptom of endometriosis, vaginal discharge is not typically associated with this condition.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Dysmenorrhea is indeed a symptom of endometriosis, but increased vaginal bleeding is not a primary symptom of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis commonly presents with symptoms including dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) and infertility.


Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A woman who is using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) experiences white vaginal discharge without itching or a foul odor. The discharge causes yellow staining on her underwear. Upon examination, the discharge reveals the presence of typical lactobacilli and an acidic pH. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased normal vaginal discharge

 

The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Leucorrhea (Increased vaginal discharge). Leucorrhea presents with excessive whitish, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge. It is non-irritant, no purulent and non-offensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents with itching and a white thick, curdy discharge.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis: Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a thin, gray, foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option D. Chlamydia infection: Chlamydia infection can by asymptomatic or present with discharge but is not associated with yellow discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased normal vaginal discharge, known as leucorrhea, can occur in women using oral contraceptive pills. This discharge is typically white or yellow, non-irritant, no purulent, no offensive, and associated with the presence of lactobacilli and an acidic pH.

questions.text: A 32 weeks pregnant woman is at risk of GDM. She would have likely had a screening test during which time of pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24-28 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is typically diagnosed during pregnancy and is due to the hormonal changes associated with pregnancy. These hormonal changes, particularly the placental hormones, cause increased insulin resistance, which generally becomes apparent after 24 weeks of gestation.

 

The optimal time to screen for GDM is between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy.

 

This period is chosen because it is when the effects of placental hormones on glucose metabolism become significant enough to detect any abnormalities in glucose tolerance.

 

Screening Methods:

 

  1. IADPSG Criteria (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups):
    • A 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is performed.
    • Blood glucose levels are checked fasting, at 1 hour, and at 2 hours after glucose intake.
    • Diagnostic criteria:
      • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL
      • 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL
      • 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
    • Any one of these values being abnormal is diagnostic of GDM.
  2. DIPSI Criteria (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India):
    • The patient does not need to be fasting.
    • A 75-gram glucose load is given, and blood glucose is checked after 2 hours.
    • A value ≥ 140 mg/dL is diagnostic of GDM.

 

Note - First visit is the time to screen for pre-existing diabetes or overt diabetes in women who may not know they are diabetic. It is not the typical time for GDM screening, which occurs later in pregnancy.

 

Educational objective:

 

The appropriate time to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus is between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy, as this is when the impact of placental hormones on glucose metabolism is most apparent.

choices.text: Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother
Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm

questions.text: Ventouse is contra-indicated in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preterm

 

Ventouse (vacuum extraction) is contraindicated in preterm deliveries due to the increased risk of neonatal complications. The head of a preterm baby is more vulnerable to injury, and the use of vacuum can lead to severe complications such as neurological damage, cephalohematoma, or skull fractures. This is because the vacuum exerts force on the baby’s head, which is particularly fragile in preterm infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother: This is not an absolute contraindication for vacuum delivery. In fact, vacuum extraction is often used when there are decreased maternal efforts during the second stage of labor.

 

Option B. Heart disease: Maternal heart disease is not a contraindication for vacuum extraction. However, it may influence the choice of delivery method to minimize maternal stress.

 

Option D. Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm: While full cervical dilation (10 cm) is ideal for vacuum extraction, it is a relative contraindication rather than an absolute one. In urgent situations where cesarean section is not feasible, vacuum extraction might still be considered even if the cervix is not fully dilated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absolute Contraindication of Ventouse:

 

  • Preterm
  • Face presentation
  • After coming head of the breech
  • IUD

choices.text: Decreased number of Lactobacilli
Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium
pH > 6.8
Epithelial thinning

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

 

  • Vaginal epithelium increases the metabolism of glycogen in pregnancy.
  • It leads to decrease in pH and makes the vaginal epithelium more acidic
  • This is because of increased lactobacilli

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased number of Lactobacilli: The number of lactobacilli are increased in the reproductive age group especially in pregnancy

 

Option C. pH > 6.8: Vaginal pH in pregnancy is acidic

 

 

Option D. Epithelial thinning: Estrogen increases the vaginal thickness in pregnancy. The vagina becomes thin in the absence of estrogen (like in menopause)

 

Educational Objective:

 

During pregnancy, the vaginal epithelium increases glycogen metabolism, leading to a more acidic environment that promotes the growth of Lactobacilli and helps protect against infections.

 

Ref: Page no 20, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vulval cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma.
  • Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval hematoma: Vulval hematomas may occur due to direct trauma or accidental injuries. They present as a localized collection of blood within the vulvar tissues, leading to swelling and bruising, but they do not typically form irregular fungating lesions.

 

Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, are commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

They appear as multiple, small, cauliflower-like growths and are not typically large, irregular, or fungating.

 

Option D. Bartholin cyst: A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland gets blocked due to infection, resulting in a buildup of glandular secretions.

 

It presents as a swelling on one side of the vaginal opening, but it is typically smooth and round, not irregular and fungating.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulvar cancer often presents as an irregular, fungating lesion on the vulva.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 337,338

choices.text: Ascending aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Superior vena-caval syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Abdominal aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Supine vena cava syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supine vena cava syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates supine hypotension syndrome, also known as supine vena cava syndrome. This condition occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is in a supine position. This compression leads to reduced venous return to the heart, causing hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. It is especially dangerous during cesarean sections, as spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension. To prevent this, a wedge is placed beneath the right hip during the procedure to tilt the patient slightly to the left, thereby relieving pressure on the vena cava.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ascending aorta syndrome: This condition is not typically associated with pregnancy and does not involve the pressure of the gravid uterus on the IVC.

 

Option B. Superior vena-caval syndrome: This syndrome involves obstruction of the superior vena cava, leading to symptoms such as facial swelling and dyspnea. It is unrelated to the position of a pregnant woman and the compression of the IVC.

 

Option C. Abdominal aorta syndrome: There is no specific syndrome by this name. The abdominal aorta may be compressed during pregnancy, but it does not lead to the symptoms associated with supine hypotension syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine vena cava syndrome occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava when the woman is in a supine position, leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.

 

Ref: Page no 2237, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: In which of the following will you NOT do induction of labor? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central Placenta Previa

 

Explanation:

 

Induction of labor involves starting labor artificially in a patient who is not already in labor, usually to expedite delivery due to various maternal or fetal indications such as fetal growth restriction, post-term pregnancy, oligohydramnios, or preeclampsia. The goal of induction is to achieve vaginal delivery.

 

However, induction is contraindicated in situations where vaginal delivery is not possible or safe, as in central placenta previa, where the placenta completely covers the cervical os. Attempting vaginal delivery in this situation can lead to severe hemorrhage as contractions begin. Therefore, a cesarean section is indicated for central placenta previa to avoid the risk of bleeding and ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oligohydramnios: Induction is indicated to avoid complications from low amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Induction is recommended at 37 weeks for mild preeclampsia and at 34 weeks for severe preeclampsia to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

Option D. PROM: Induction is required if labor does not start spontaneously to prevent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Induction of labor is contraindicated in central placenta previa due to the risk of severe hemorrhage, necessitating a cesarean section for safe delivery.

choices.text: Activated protein C

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady had an uneventful vaginal delivery. On postpartum day 1, she presented with postpartum hemorrhage and complains of visual changes and severe headache. A few hours after the complaint, she is found to be in an unresponsive state and is intubated and put on ventilation. On further examination, she has a BP of 60/40 mmHg and tachycardia, blood sugar is 48 mg/dL. Hematocrit and WBC count was normal. Which of the following drugs would help reverse this state? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described—postpartum hemorrhage followed by severe headache, visual changes, hypotension, and unresponsiveness—suggests Sheehan syndrome. This condition arises from pituitary apoplexy, which is pituitary infarction secondary to severe blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

  • Sheehan Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by pituitary gland failure due to substantial blood loss during delivery. The symptoms include persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, lactation failure, headache, visual deficits, and in severe cases, shock, CNS hemorrhage, and even death.
  • Steroids: Hormone replacement with glucocorticoids (steroids) is crucial for managing Sheehan syndrome. Steroids address the adrenal insufficiency and help stabilize the patient’s condition. Initially, glucocorticoids are administered, followed by other hormone replacements as needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inj. Dobutamine: Dobutamine is a beta-agonist used for managing cardiac failure and hypotension. While it may help with blood pressure, it does not address the underlying issue of pituitary failure and would not be the primary treatment for Sheehan syndrome.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: Thyroxine (T4) is a thyroid hormone used in thyroid hormone replacement therapy. While it might be needed later if thyroid function is affected, it does not directly address the acute symptoms of Sheehan syndrome, which is primarily managed with steroids.

 

Option D. Activated Protein C: Activated protein C is used in the management of severe sepsis and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), but it does not treat the pituitary dysfunction associated with Sheehan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan syndrome is treated primarily with glucocorticoid (steroid) therapy to manage pituitary failure following significant blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

Ref: Page 378, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Studdiford criteria

 

  • Studdiford Criteria is for diagnosis of Primary abdominal pregnancy
    • Both tubes and ovaries normal with no marks of injury
    • Utero-peritoneal fistula should not be seen
    • The placenta should be attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiegelberg Criteria: Spiegelberg Criteria is for Ovarian ectopic

 

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestation sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • The gestation sac in the ovary must be connected to the uterus by the ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall on histopathology

 

Option B. Rubin criteria: Rubin criteria is for Cervical pregnancy

 

Option D. Ring of fire: Ring of fire is a sign seen on USG-Color doppler in an unruptured tubal ectopic

 

Educational Objective:

 

Studdiford Criteria are used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy. This criterion involves:

 

  1. Ensuring that both fallopian tubes and ovaries are normal with no signs of injury.
  2. Confirming that no utero-peritoneal fistula is present.
  3. Verifying that the placenta is attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface.

 

These criteria help distinguish primary abdominal pregnancy from other types of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Ref: Page no 219, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine evaluation. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 24 weeks. Ultrasonography revealed decreased amniotic fluid. Which of the following conditions would have led to this presentation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis: Absence of both kidneys, leading to a lack of urine production, which is a major component of amniotic fluid.
    • Bilateral dysplastic kidneys: Kidneys that do not function properly, also leading to reduced urine output.
    • Bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease: This genetic disorder causes the kidneys to develop cysts, impairing their function.
    • Complex genito-urinary anomalies: Conditions like persistent cloaca and sirenomelia can affect kidney and urinary tract development, leading to oligohydramnios.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal Fistula: Tracheoesophageal fistula typically leads to polyhydramnios due to an obstruction to swallowing, resulting in an accumulation of amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Cardiac Abnormalities: Cardiac abnormalities usually lead to cardiac failure, which can result in fetal hydrops and polyhydramnios due to fluid accumulation in various fetal compartments.

 

Option D. Ureteral Stricture: Ureteral stricture will not lead to oligohydramnios unless there is bilateral involvement, which would be less common than the systemic impact of renal agenesis or other significant renal anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be caused by renal anomalies, with bilateral renal agenesis being a primary condition leading to reduced amniotic fluid levels.

 

Ref: Page no 670, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: OCP + Anti androgen
Counsel for metabolic syndrome

questions.text: A young girl presents with menstrual irregularity, acne, increased hair growth with a Ferriman Gallway score of 6, and a BMI of 29. Her mother has diabetes. Which is not a management option?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) OCP + Anti androgen

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly used alone for managing symptoms like acne and menstrual irregularity in PCOS. The addition of anti-androgens is typically reserved for cases where OCPs alone do not manage hirsutism effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCP: OCPs are a standard treatment for managing menstrual irregularities and hyperandrogenism.

 

Option C. Yoga + Exercise: Yoga and exercise are recommended for weight management and improving insulin sensitivity.

 

Option D. Counsel for metabolic syndrome: Counseling for metabolic syndrome is crucial given her high BMI and family history of diabetes.

 

Educational objective:

 

In managing PCOS-like symptoms, initial treatment often starts with OCPs. Additional treatments like anti-androgens are considered if initial treatments are insufficient. Lifestyle modifications are always beneficial.

choices.text: Do a routine episiotomy
Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head
Never give warm compress to the perineum
Perform labor in lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO guidelines for the management of second stage of labor? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head

 

Explanation:

 

The WHO Recommendations 2018 for the intrapartum second stage of labor emphasize the importance of a positive birth experience. The guidelines suggest manual support to the perineum to maintain the flexion of the fetal head, which helps in reducing perineal trauma.

 

WHO Recommendations 2018 (Intrapartum Second Stage):

 

Recommended:

 

  • Duration of the second stage in primigravida: up to 3 hours; in multigravida: up to 2 hours
  • Allowing the birthing position of choice
  • Encouraging the mother to follow her own urge to push
  • Reducing perineal trauma by using techniques such as hands-on guarding, warm compresses, and perineal massage

 

Not recommended:

 

  • Routine episiotomy
  • Fundal pressure

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Do a routine episiotomy: This is not recommended as a routine practice according to WHO guidelines. Episiotomy should only be performed when clinically indicated.

 

Option C. Never give warm compress to the perineum: This is incorrect. Warm compresses to the perineum are recommended to help reduce perineal trauma.

 

Option D. Perform labor in lithotomy position: The WHO guidelines recommend allowing the woman to choose her birthing position, rather than mandating the lithotomy position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Manual support to the perineum and maintaining the flexion of the fetal head are part of the WHO recommendations for the second stage of labor to reduce perineal trauma and ensure a positive birth experience.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

questions.text: All are long acting reversible methods of contraception, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Female sterilization

 

Explanation:

 

Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARC) are those which are administered at a frequency of less than once per month. LARC methods include:

 

  • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years.
  • Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years.
  • Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestin injection: This is a form of LARC. Injectable contraceptives like DMPA and NET-EN are given at intervals of 2 to 3 months.

 

Option B. Progestin implants: These are also considered LARC. Implanon and Norplant II are examples of progestin implants with a duration of action up to 3 years.

 

Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices: Both types of IUDs are classified as LARC. The CuT 380A lasts for up to 10 years, and the LNG IUD lasts for up to 5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC) include intrauterine devices (IUDs), progestin implants, and injectable contraceptives, but do not include permanent methods like female sterilization.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 491-492,479,

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ampulla

 

Explanation:

 

 

Ampulla:

 

  • The ampulla is the widest section of the fallopian tube and is the most common site for fertilization.
  • This region provides an optimal environment for the sperm to meet the ovum and for the subsequent fertilization process to occur.
  • The ampulla is also the most common site of ectopic pregnancy, where a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.

 

Structure of the Fallopian Tube:

 

The fallopian tube has four main parts:

 

  1. Infundibulum: The funnel-shaped opening near the ovary with finger-like projections called fimbriae.
  2. Ampulla: The widest and longest part where fertilization typically occurs.
  3. Isthmus: A narrow section adjacent to the uterus.
  4. Interstitial (or intramural): The part that traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isthmus: The isthmus is the narrow section of the fallopian tube close to the uterus. While it plays a role in the transport of the fertilized egg to the uterus, it is not the primary site for fertilization.

 

Option C. Interstitial: This portion of the fallopian tube traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity. It is not typically where fertilization occurs.

 

Option D. Infundibular: The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped opening near the ovary, equipped with fimbriae to help capture the released ovum. Fertilization does not typically occur here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fertilization typically occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, which is the widest and longest part of the tube.

 

Ref: Page no 23, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A woman presents with bleeding since 2 days and abdominal pain. Her LMP was 6 weeks back. An ultrasound shows fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

The correct answer is Ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition is an emergency where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tube. As the pregnancy grows, it can cause the tube to rupture, leading to internal bleeding. The classic presentation of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy includes:

 

  • Abdominal pain: Due to the rupture and internal bleeding.
  • Vaginal bleeding: Occurs as a result of the ectopic pregnancy.
  • History of amenorrhea (missed period): Indicates an early pregnancy.
  • Fluid in the pouch of Douglas: This is a key diagnostic clue. The pouch of Douglas is the lowest point of the female pelvis, located between the uterus and the rectum. In the case of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, blood often collects here, visible as fluid on an ultrasound.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, typically occurring in the third trimester. It is characterized by severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a rigid, tender uterus. This scenario does not fit the description of the early pregnancy situation described in the question.

 

Option B. Placenta previa: This condition occurs when the placenta covers the cervix either partially or completely. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester, not in the first trimester as described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Missed abortion: A missed abortion refers to a situation where the fetus has died but has not been expelled from the uterus. It usually presents with an absence of fetal heart tones on ultrasound and a uterus that is smaller than expected for gestational age. There would not typically be fluid in the pouch of Douglas, which is more indicative of intraperitoneal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy, if a patient presents with abdominal pain, bleeding, and a history of missed periods, with fluid in the pouch of Douglas seen on ultrasound, the most likely diagnosis is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition requires immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed, and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leiomyoma

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • The given image shows a large leiomyoma. (Submucosal, i.e., the location of the fibroid is in the endometrial cavity)
  • Patients usually present with heavy menstrual bleeding.
  • According to their location, fibroids are classified according to FIGO classification.
  • Most common HPE features are: Whorled appearance in cross section, well circumscribed firm lesion.  ﻿
  • The most common degeneration associated with myomas is cystic degeneration.
  • Red degeneration is common during pregnancy.

 

 

FIGO Classification of Fibroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometrial carcinoma: This will show an irregular growth In the endometrial cavity as shown in the image

 

 

Option C. Endometrial polyp: This will appear as a soft fleshy projection in the endometrial cavity as shown in the image

 

 

Option D. Adenomyosis: This usually will be a globular enlargement of the uterus with myometrial thickening as shown below

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leiomyomas, or fibroids, are the most common benign tumors of the uterus, often presenting with heavy menstrual bleeding. They are characterized by a whorled appearance in cross section and a well-circumscribed, firm lesion.

questions.text: A woman presents with white vaginal discharge. On preparing a vaginal smear, pseudo hyphae are seen. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candidiasis

 

The presence of pseudohyphae on a vaginal smear is indicative of a fungal infection, specifically candidiasis. Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans, are known to form pseudohyphae as part of their growth pattern. This finding, along with white vaginal discharge, supports the diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Candidiasis: Characterized by white, thick, curd-like vaginal discharge and the presence of pseudohyphae and spores on microscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomonas: Identified by the presence of flagellated protozoa (Trichomonas vaginalis) on the smear.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis: Diagnosed by the presence of clue cells on the smear, which are vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, giving a stippled appearance.

 

Option D. Physiological: Normal vaginal discharge, which shows normal vaginal epithelial cells without any pathogenic organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of pseudo-hyphae on a vaginal smear with white discharge is diagnostic of candidiasis.

questions.text: During delivery of a 30y G2P1L1 with previous LSCS, the head was delivered but the shoulders got stuck. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shoulder dystocia

 

Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency where, after the delivery of the fetal head, the shoulders fail to deliver within a typical interval. The definition of shoulder dystocia includes a delivery interval between the head and the shoulders exceeding one minute or requiring specific maneuvers to release the shoulders. This condition occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts behind the maternal pubic symphysis or, less commonly, the posterior shoulder impacts the sacral promontory.

 

In this scenario, the head was delivered, but the shoulders got stuck, fitting the clinical definition of shoulder dystocia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPD (Cephalopelvic Disproportion): This is incorrect as CPD refers to a mismatch between the size of the fetal head and the maternal pelvis, preventing the fetal head from entering or passing through the birth canal. It does not specifically describe the situation where the shoulders get stuck after the head is delivered.

 

Option C. Occipito posterior: This option is incorrect because it refers to the fetal head being positioned posteriorly in the pelvis, which can cause prolonged labor but does not directly result in shoulder dystocia. In occipito posterior positions, the delivery complication is typically a "face to pubis" delivery, not shoulder entrapment.

 

Option D. Transverse lie: This is incorrect as it describes a fetal position where the fetus lies horizontally in the uterus, which leads to complications like neglected shoulder with hand prolapse if the membranes rupture. The presentation is the shoulder, not the head, which means it does not fit the scenario where the head is delivered but the shoulders are stuck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shoulder dystocia is diagnosed when the shoulders fail to deliver within a minute after the head or require specific maneuvers for delivery.

choices.text: Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasions

questions.text: In superfecundation, which of the following is seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasions

 

Explanation:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two different ova released in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from separate acts of intercourse occurring within a short period of time. This can result in twins with different fathers if the sperm comes from two different men, a phenomenon known as heteropaternal superfecundation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse: This describes the fertilization of two ova by sperm from a single act of intercourse, which is not superfecundation but simply the result of one intercourse fertilizing two ova simultaneously.

 

Option C. Both of the above: While it includes the correct scenario of superfecundation, it also includes an incorrect scenario, making it partially correct.

 

Option D. None of the above: This indicates that none of the given scenarios are correct, which is inaccurate as option B is correct.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova released during the same menstrual cycle by sperm from separate acts of intercourse.

 

Ref: Page 227, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Opinion of 1 doctor
Opinion of 2 doctors
Husband’s permission with 1 doctor
Permission of medical board

questions.text: A fetus diagnosed with neural tube defect at 21 weeks. The parents want an MTP at 21 weeks. What opinions are required? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Opinion of 2 doctors

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, which was amended in 2021, significant changes were made to the requirements for performing an MTP in India.

 

Under the old act, MTP was allowed up to 20 weeks, with the opinion of one registered medical practitioner (RMP) required up to 12 weeks, and the opinion of two RMPs required from 12 to 20 weeks.

 

The 2021 amendment extended the permissible period for MTP to 24 weeks. The new guidelines specify that:

 

  • Up to 20 weeks, the opinion of one RMP or gynecologist is required.
  • From 20 to 24 weeks, the opinion of two gynecologists is required.
  • For pregnancies beyond 24 weeks, MTP can be performed only if there is a substantial fetal anomaly, which must be determined by a medical board. This board typically consists of specialists such as a radiologist, a gynecologist, a pediatrician, and other relevant subspecialists based on the nature of the anomaly.

 

In this scenario, since the fetus is diagnosed with a neural tube defect at 21 weeks and the parents request an MTP, the opinion of two doctors is required.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Opinion of 1 doctor: This is required only up to 20 weeks of pregnancy, not beyond.

 

Option C. Husband’s permission with 1 doctor: The husband’s permission is not a requirement under the MTP Act.

 

Option D. Permission of medical board: This is required for performing MTP after 24 weeks if there is a substantial fetal anomaly.

 

Educational objective

 

For an MTP between 20 to 24 weeks of pregnancy, the opinion of two gynecologists is required as per the 2021 amendment to the MTP Act in India.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. The biopsy will help in diagnosing the nature of the lesion, which is crucial for further management.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Conization: Conization is an excisional procedure done once biopsy-proven intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step when a visible lesion is present and needs to be assessed.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure done for CIN 1 or 2. It is not suitable for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding without a prior biopsy.

 

Option D. Pap smear: Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. In the presence of a visible mass, a direct biopsy is more appropriate.

 

Educational Objective:
