For a symptomatic patient with postcoital bleeding and a visible lesion on the cervix, the next step is a targeted biopsy to diagnose the nature of the lesion.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg662, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg345

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

 

Explanation

 

  • In the given case scenario, vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management.
  • This is also called as Ward Mayo repair
  • This is recommended to patients who satisfy the following criteria:
    • >40 years of age
    • Have completed their families
    • Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fothergill repair: This is also known as Manchester repair and involves conserving the uterus. In this procedure, cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments is done. It is done in young women who have completed their families with utero-vaginal prolapse.

 

Option B. Sling operation: This is preferred in women who are young, nulliparous (yet to have children/ complete their families) with prolapse

 

Option D. Shirodkar procedure: This is a modification of Manchester/ Fothergill surgery and does not include cervical amputation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair (Ward Mayo repair) is the preferred management for older women (>40 years) with third degree uterine prolapse who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

 

Ref: Page 221, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: 10% buffered formalin
95% ethyl alcohol
None of the above

questions.text: Fixative for PAP smear: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 95% ethyl alcohol

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. This fixative preserves the cellular detail necessary for accurate cytological evaluation by preventing cellular autolysis and degradation. The use of 95% ethyl alcohol ensures that the cells maintain their morphology, which is critical for detecting abnormalities such as dysplasia or carcinoma.

 

  • 95% Ethyl Alcohol: This is the standard fixative for Pap smears, ensuring optimal preservation of cellular details.
  • Ethanol Spray: In modern practice, an ethanol spray fixative is available, which can be conveniently used in an office setting to fix the smear immediately after it is taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10% buffered formalin: This fixative is typically used for histological specimens rather than cytological smears like the Pap test.

 

Option C. Air dried: Air drying is not recommended for Pap smears as it can cause cellular distortion and artifacts, which complicate the interpretation of the smear.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as 95% ethyl alcohol is the correct fixative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol, which preserves cellular morphology necessary for accurate cytological evaluation.

 

Ref: Page no 271, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely seen in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Condyloma accuminata

 

  • Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are suggestive of condyloma acuminata (genital warts).
  • The main causative agent is HPV-6 and 11.
  • Lesions: Typically, they grow in clusters along a narrow stalk giving it a cauliflower appearance but at times the stalk may be broad and thick
  • Treatment: Cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision or topical use of 5-fluorouracil, trichloro-acetic acid or intralesional interferon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum:

 

  • Caused by a pox virus transmitted by body contact or towels or clothing.
  • It is commonly seen in immunodeficient subject or with HIV infections.
  • The lesions vary in size up to 1 cm, dome shaped, pearly-white in colour and often umbilicated.
  • They are usually multiple and can occur anywhere in the skin and genitalia.
  • Microscopic appearance reveals numerous inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies) in the cytoplasm of the cells with Giemsa stain.
  • Treatment: 
    • Evacuation of caseous material from the nodule under local anaesthetic is done.
    • The floor of the nodule is then treated chemically with ferric sub-sulphate or trichloroacetic acid (85%) solution.
    • Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen is applied until a halo of ice is formed around the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Chancroid:

 

  • Chancroid is a bacterial sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by infection with Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • It is characterized by painful necrotizing genital ulcers that may be accompanied by inguinal lymphadenopathy. 

 

 

Option D. Herpes:

 

  • The causative organism is herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 and 2.
  • It is usually transmitted sexually by an infected partner/ oro-genital contact.
  • The incubation period is 2–14 days.
  • Clinical Features: 
    • Initially, red painful inflammatory areas appear commonly on the clitoris, labia, vestibule, vagina, perineum, and cervix.
    • Multiple vesicles appear which progress into multiple shallow ulcers and ultimately heal up spontaneously by crusting.
    • It takes about 3 weeks to complete the process.
    • Inguinal lymphadenopathy occurs.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever, malaise, and headache.
    •  There may be vulvar burning, pruritus, dysuria, or retention of urine.
  • Treatment: Acyclovir

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata (genital warts) are characterized by multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal, caused by HPV-6 and 11, and treated with cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision, or topical agents.

 

Ref: Page no 153, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with spotting PV following insertion of an IUD. What is the best management? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron supplementation

 

This is the recommendation by the ministry of health and family welfare. Usually spotting settles done in a few months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remove the IUD: Removal of the IUD is not indicated for mild spotting. It is a normal response and should be managed conservatively.

 

Option C. Oral antibiotics: Antibiotics are not required unless there is evidence of an infection, which is not indicated by mere spotting.

 

Option D. Reassurance and observe: Spotting following the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD) is a common and expected side effect. It typically occurs due to the body's inflammatory response to the new device in the uterus, which can cause mild cramping and spotting. The best management in this situation is to reassure the patient and observe the symptoms. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be given to alleviate cramps and reduce spotting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron supplementation are crucial in managing post-IUCD insertion bleeding to prevent anemia. If bleeding persists, further action, such as removing the IUCD, may be necessary.

choices.text: Metronidazole
Fluconazole
Clindamycin

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of pregnant woman with bacterial vaginosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metronidazole

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis (BV) in pregnant women. This choice is based on its efficacy in addressing the anaerobic bacterial overgrowth that characterizes BV. It is generally prescribed as 200 mg three times daily for 7 days during pregnancy. While Clindamycin is also used for BV and can be an alternative, Metronidazole remains the preferred treatment due to its effectiveness and established safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluconazole: This drug is used for the treatment of fungal infections like candidiasis, not bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option C. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an alternative treatment for BV, especially if Metronidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. However, Metronidazole is typically preferred.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: This antibiotic is generally used for various bacterial infections but is not the first choice for BV. It is not typically used for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A pregnant lady with 34 weeks of amenorrhea has the following findings: LDH - 700 IU/L, platelets - 75,000/ mm3, serum bilirubin - 1.5 mg/dL, SGOT - 200 U/L, SGPT - 150 U/L, and BP - 140/96 mm Hg. Her coagulation profile and renal function tests are normal. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HELLP syndrome

 

HELLP Syndrome:

 

  • The given clinical scenario with elevated liver enzymes (SGOT and SGPT), elevated bilirubin, low platelet count, and hypertension is indicative of HELLP syndrome.
  • HELLP is an acronym for:
    • Hemolysis (H): Evidence of hemolysis can include elevated LDH.
    • Elevated Liver enzymes (EL): Both SGOT and SGPT are elevated.
    • Low Platelet count (LP): Platelet count is significantly reduced (below 100,000/mm³).
  • This syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia and requires immediate medical attention.
  • Management often involves the termination of pregnancy, with steroid cover for fetal lung maturity and magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for seizure prophylaxis and neuroprotection of the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy:

 

  • This condition typically occurs during the late second and third trimesters.
  • Diagnosis is based on the Swansea Criteria, requiring 6 or more specific findings, which often include renal impairment, liver impairment, hypoglycemia, and coagulation defects.
  • Liver biopsy would show microvascular steatosis.

 

 

Option C. Viral Hepatitis:

 

  • Viral hepatitis can occur at any gestational age and presents with jaundice.
  • It typically involves markedly elevated bilirubin and significantly raised SGOT and SGPT levels.
  • This scenario lacks the characteristic very high bilirubin levels seen in viral hepatitis.

 

Option D. Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy:

 

  • Usually occurs in the third trimester and presents with pruritus.
  • Lab findings typically show mildly elevated bilirubin, elevated SGOT and SGPT, and characteristically raised serum bile acids.
  • Renal impairment, high BP, and coagulation abnormalities are not seen in intrahepatic cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. It is a severe form of preeclampsia and necessitates urgent medical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no 1809, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation and presents with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. On examination, fetal movements are normal, fetal parts not easily felt and muffled fetal heartbeat is heard. Symphysis fundal height came out to be 41 cm. Per abdomen examination reveals tense abdomen but not tender. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyhydramnios

 

The given scenario of 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

 

Polyhydramnios

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placenta: Abruption Placenta presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.

 

Option B. Hydrocephalus of fetus: Hydrocephalus of the fetus leads to increased head circumference in the fetus, which may cause an increased symphysis fundal height but unlikely to cause breathlessness and abdominal distension to this extent.

 

Option D. Fetal-maternal ascites: Patients of Fetal-maternal ascites commonly present with edema, proteinuria, hypertension, elevated liver enzymes and headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, it most likely points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

questions.text: Which infection contracted in pregnancy won't be teratogenic?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV 2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV 2) primarily causes genital infections and is not generally teratogenic. It poses risks primarily at delivery if there is an active infection, leading to neonatal herpes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Rubella is highly teratogenic, especially if contracted in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common cause of congenital infections and can result in severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Chicken pox: Chickenpox (Varicella) can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which is teratogenic.

 

Educational objective:

 

Among the listed infections, HSV 2 is not considered teratogenic, although it requires careful management to prevent neonatal transmission during delivery.

choices.text: HRT to induce puberty

questions.text: A 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea, no breast development and Prader 3 genitalia was found to have raised FSH. Her karyotype revealed 45 X0/46 XY and an ultrasound revealed Mullerian structures with poorly visualized gonads. What would be the next line of management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral gonadectomy

 

  • This patient has gonadal dysgenesis with virilization (Prader 3 classification is used to describe the degree of virilization of external genitalia)

 

 

  • If a Y-chromosome is identified during evaluation of primary amenorrhoea, laparoscopic prophylactic gonadectomy is recommended at the time of diagnosis to eliminate the risk of malignancy as dysgenetic gonads have a very high risk of malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. HRT to induce puberty: After gonadectomy, then HRT can be given for secondary sexual development

 

Option D. Clitoroplasty and Option A. vaginoplasty and other surgeries to correct the virilization may be required but the immediate next step would be to do gonadectomy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Whenever there is 46XY with primary amenorrhoea, always gonadectomy needs to be done in view of high risk of malignancy in dysgenetic gonads

 

Ref: Speroff’s Textbook of Reproductive Medicine

choices.text: Cervical mucus thickening
Increase GnRH release

questions.text: Oral contraceptives act by all of the following mechanisms except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase GnRH release

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) function through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) is not one of them. In fact, OCPs inhibit the release of GnRH.

 

Mechanisms of action of OCPs:

 

  • Inhibit ovulation: By suppressing the release of GnRH, and consequently, the pituitary secretion of Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH), OCPs prevent the development and release of an ovum.
  • Prevent implantation: OCPs create a less favorable endometrial environment for implantation of a fertilized egg.
  • Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the viscosity of cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an ovum.
  • Produce static endometrial hypoplasia: OCPs cause the endometrial lining to remain thin, which further prevents implantation.
  • Affect tubal motility: OCPs can alter the motility of the fallopian tubes, reducing the likelihood of sperm meeting an ovum.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Inhibit implantation: OCPs prevent the endometrium from becoming suitable for implantation.

 

Option B. Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the thickness of cervical mucus to block sperm penetration.

 

Option C. Inhibit ovulation: OCPs suppress the hormonal signals that trigger ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral contraceptive pills prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, preventing implantation, thickening cervical mucus, producing static endometrial hypoplasia, and affecting tubal motility. They do not increase GnRH release; rather, they inhibit it.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition 485

choices.text: MgSO4
Nifedipine
Ritoridine

questions.text: In preterm labor which drug has a neuro-protective role? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MgSO4

 

Explanation:

 

Neuroprotection in preterm labor:

 

  • The drug given is MgSO4.
  • It reduces the incidence of cerebral palsy and neurodevelopmental delay.
  • IV MgSO4 should be offered for neuroprotection of the baby to all women between 24+0 and 29+6 weeks who are:
    • In established preterm labor or
    • Having a planned preterm birth within 24 hours.
  • It can be considered for neuroprotection of the baby for women between 30+0 and 33+6 weeks.
  • Dose: 4 g intravenous bolus of magnesium sulfate over 15 minutes, followed by an intravenous infusion of 1 g per hour until the birth or for 24 hours (whichever is sooner).

 

Uses of MgSO4 in Obstetrics:

 

  1. Treatment of Eclampsia (Anti-seizure)
  2. Prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia (to prevent eclampsia)
  3. As a tocolytic in preterm labor
  4. As a neuroprotective drug in preterm labor (especially < 30 weeks)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: A calcium channel blocker used as a tocolytic and antihypertensive but has no role in neuroprotection.

 

Option C. Ritodrine: A beta-sympathomimetic used as a tocolytic but has no neuroprotective role.

 

Option D. Isoxsuprine: Another beta-sympathomimetic used as a tocolytic without neuroprotective properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm labor, MgSO4 is used for neuroprotection, reducing the incidence of cerebral palsy and neurodevelopmental delay in preterm infants.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 538

questions.text: A 24y woman presents with suspected ovarian torsion. What is the investigation of choice? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ultrasound + Color Doppler

 

Ultrasound combined with Color Doppler is the investigation of choice for suspected ovarian torsion.

 

 

This combination is highly effective in identifying the condition. When a patient presents with symptoms of severe abdominal pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting, which is not relieved by analgesics, ovarian torsion should be considered, particularly if an adnexal mass is present. On the ultrasound with Color Doppler, the characteristic "whirlpool sign" can be observed, indicating twisted ovarian vessels and confirming the diagnosis.

 

The use of Color Doppler helps in assessing the blood flow to the ovary. In cases of torsion, blood flow may be absent, leading to ovarian ischemia. A laparoscopy can further confirm the diagnosis, revealing a twisted ovarian pedicle and a necrotic ovary if the torsion is prolonged. Treatment involves laparoscopic detorsion, where the twisted ovary is untwisted. If blood flow returns, a cystectomy may be performed to remove any cysts. If the ovary remains necrotic, an ovariectomy may be necessary to remove the affected ovary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound + Xray: While an ultrasound is useful, an Xray does not provide additional value in diagnosing ovarian torsion. X-rays are not effective in visualizing soft tissues or blood flow.

 

Option C. Ultrasound + DSA: Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is more invasive and not typically used for diagnosing ovarian torsion. It is mainly used for detailed vascular imaging.

 

Option D. MRI: MRI can provide detailed images but is not the first-line investigation due to its higher cost and limited availability compared to ultrasound with Color Doppler.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice for suspected ovarian torsion is an ultrasound combined with Color Doppler, which helps visualize the characteristic whirlpool sign and assess blood flow to the ovary.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD as a known case of cervical cancer. On further evaluation, the pelvic side wall was found to be involved, and hydronephrosis was also seen. Identify the stage of cervical cancer. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3B

 

Stage 3B cervical cancer is characterized by the involvement of the pelvic side wall and the presence of hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney due to ureteric obstruction. In this stage, the cancer has extended to the lateral pelvic wall, and often the tumor affects the ureter, leading to obstructive uropathy. This progression indicates a significant local spread of the disease, distinguishing it from earlier stages where cancer is confined closer to the cervix or upper parts of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2B: Stage 2B cervical cancer involves the spread of cancer into the parametrium but does not reach the lateral pelvic wall. It does not involve hydronephrosis or ureteric obstruction, which are key features distinguishing Stage 3B.

 

Option B. 3A: Stage 3A involves the spread of cancer to the lower third of the vagina without extension to the pelvic wall or causing hydronephrosis. It does not involve the pelvic side wall or ureteric complications, unlike Stage 3B.

 

Option D. 3C: Stage 3C is characterized by the spread of cancer to pelvic or para-aortic lymph nodes but does not necessarily involve the pelvic side wall or hydronephrosis. Stage 3C is further divided into 3C1 (pelvic lymph nodes) and 3C2 (para-aortic lymph nodes), differing from the pelvic side wall involvement seen in Stage 3B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stages of cervical cancer:
